title: France
name: France
description:
A Map by Jklmiller

These are the places we would like to see/things we would like to do in France

properties.name: Amiens Cathedral
properties.description: Posted by Jklmiller    Amiens Cathedral, in the heart of Picardy, is one of the largest \'classic\' Gothic churches of the 13th century. It is notable for the coherence of its plan, the beauty of its three-tier interior elevation and the particularly fine display of sculptures on the principal facade and in the south transept.

properties.name: Basilica of the Sacré Cœur
properties.description: Posted by Jklmiller48.886681n 2.342706eThis article relates to the Sacré-Cœur Basilica in France. For the basilica with the same French name in Belgium, see Basilica of the Sacred Heart, Belgium. Basilica of Sacré-Cœur, as seen from the base of the butte Montmartre. The basilica itselfThe Sacré-Cœur Basilica (Basilique du Sacré-Cœur, "Basilica of the Sacred Heart") is a Roman Catholic church and popular landmark in Paris, France.

properties.name: Carcassonne
properties.description: Posted by Jklmillercarcassonne france(Location: 43°13′N 02°22′E) (Carcassona in Occitan) is a fortified French town, in the Aude département, of which it is the préfecture, in the former province of Languedoc. It is separated into the fortified Cité de Carcassonne and the more expansive lower city, the ville basse. The folk etymology, involving a châtelaine named Carcas, a ruse ending a siege and the joyous ringing of bells ("Carcas sonne"), though memorialized in a neo-Gothic sculpture of Mme Carcas on a column near the Narbonne Gate, is of modern invention. The fortress was added to the UNESCO list of World Heritage Sites in 1997.

properties.name: Carnac
properties.description: Posted by SystemCarnac

properties.name: Chartres Cathedral
properties.description: Posted by Jklmiller    Partly built starting in 1145, and then reconstructed over a 26-year period after the fire of 1194, Chartres Cathedral marks the high point of French Gothic art. The vast nave, in pure ogival style, the porches adorned with fine sculptures from the middle of the 12th century, and the magnificent 12th- and 13th-century stained-glass windows, all in remarkable condition, combine to make it a masterpiece.

properties.name: Chateau de Tredion
properties.description: Posted by JklmillerBuilt in the 1350s, Trédion Manor belonged to the Dukes of Brittany. The vast surrounding forests made it a superb location for hunting. Some famous names have owned Trédion over the centuries: the Malestroits, Jean IV of Rieux, the Marquess of Nesle, Guy-Paul de Coligny, the Princess of Salm, Pierre II of Sérent, Charles Fouquet in 1683 (a distant relative of Fouquet the Intendant, who was the source of the legend of the Treasure of Trédion, said to be buried at the foot of an oak tree), etc. These were followed by members of the Bourgeoisie and Petite Noblesse.

properties.name: Cistercian Abbey of Fontenay
properties.description: Posted by Jklmiller    This stark Burgundian monastery was founded by St Bernard in 1119. With its church, cloister, refectory, sleeping quarters, bakery and ironworks, it is an excellent illustration of the ideal of self-sufficiency as practised by the earliest communities of Cistercian monks.

properties.name: Decorated Grottoes of the Vézère Valley
properties.description: Posted by Jklmiller    The Vézère valley contains 147 prehistoric sites dating from the Palaeolithic and 25 decorated caves. It is particularly interesting from an ethnological and anthropological, as well as an aesthetic point of view because of its cave paintings, especially those of the Lascaux Cave, whose discovery in 1940 was of great importance for the history of prehistoric art. The hunting scenes show some 100 animal figures, which are remarkable for their detail, rich colours and lifelike quality.

properties.name: Eiffel Tower
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishingParis, FranceA symbol of Paris worldwide. 985\' high rugged tracery of iron work. Commission from competition victory. A lot of people hang out and camp out on the lawn next to the tower during the summer months. I always liked to take a bottle of wine to Trocadero at about midnight to watch the Tower\'s lights go off for the night. There are some good museums not far from the Eiffel Tower. Musee Guimet and the Palais de Tokyo come to mind.

properties.name: Fontainne des Innocents
properties.description: Posted by Charlieblue

properties.name: Ile Callot - Heures de passages en fonction des marees
properties.description: Posted by PiotrL\'ile est relié par "terre" à Carantec au gré des marées Blog Ile Callot

properties.name: Les Catacombes de Paris
properties.description: Posted by Jklmiller48.83379400 2.33235000The Catacombs of Paris is a famous burial place in Paris, France. It is a network of subterranean tunnels and rooms located in what were Roman-era limestone quarries. The quarries were converted into a mass tomb near the end of the 18th century. It is most widely known as "the catacombs", but the official title is "les carrières de Paris" or "the quarries of Paris."

properties.name: Lisieux, France
properties.description: Posted by JklmillerlisieuxThe beautiful statue of St. Therese of Lisieux, the beloved Little Flower, welcomes visitors to the National Shrine of St. Therese. This is the same statue that welcomed devotees of Therese at the the original Shrine at St. Clara\'s Church in Chicago which was destroyed by fire in 1975. Fortunately, the statue survived, though badly damaged. Now restored to its full glory, St. Therese with her serene and beautiful gaze continues to embrace pilgrims at this peaceful, prayerful place of pilgrimage.

properties.name: Louvre Museum
properties.description: Posted by Paiges "Now?" Langdon managed. "It\'s after midnight." "Am I correct that you were scheduled to meet with the curator of the Louvre this evening?" Langdon felt a sudden urge of uneasiness. He and the revered curator Jacques Sauniere had been slated to meet for drinks after Langdon\'s lecture tonight, but Sauniere had never shown up. "Yes. How did you know that?" "We found your name in his daily planner." "I trust nothing is wrong?" The agent gave dire sigh and slid a Polaroid snapshot through the narrow opening in the door. When Langdon saw the photo, his entire body went rigid. "This photo was taken less than an hour ago. Inside the Louvre." pg. 11 of The Da Vinci Code by Dan Brown, 2003 Louvre Museum. The main location of Dan Brown\'s novel and the subsequent movie.

properties.name: Mont-Saint-Michel
properties.description: Posted by Citycyclist Mont-Saint-Michel, FranceAnother one of those must-visit places, and well worth it.

properties.name: Mont-Saint-Michel and its Bay
properties.description: Posted by Jklmiller    Perched on a rocky islet in the midst of vast sandbanks exposed to powerful tides between Normandy and Brittany stand the \'Wonder of the West\', a Gothic-style Benedictine abbey dedicated to the archangel St Michael, and the village that grew up in the shadow of its great walls. Built between the 11th and 16th centuries, the abbey is a technical and artistic , having had to adapt to the problems posed by this unique natural site.

properties.name: Notre Dame
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishingParis, France

properties.name: Opéra Garnier à Paris
properties.description: Posted by Jklmiller48.872005 2.331462The Palais Garnier is an opera house, a grand landmark at the northern end of the Avenue de l\'Opéra in the IXe arrondissement of Paris, France. It is regarded as one of the architectural masterpieces of its time. Built in Neo-baroque style, it is the thirteenth theatre to house the Paris Opera since it was founded by Louis XIV in 1669. It seats 1,979. It was often also called the Paris Opera, but since the building of the Opéra Bastille in 1989, it is referred to as the Opéra Garnier.

properties.name: Palace and Park of Fontainebleau
properties.description: Posted by Jklmiller    Used by the kings of France from the 12th century, the medieval royal hunting lodge of Fontainebleau, standing at the heart of a vast forest in the Ile-de-France, was transformed, enlarged and embellished in the 16th century by François I, who wanted to make a \'New Rome\' of it. Surrounded by an immense park, the Italianate palace combines Renaissance and French artistic traditions.

properties.name: Palace and Park of Versailles
properties.description: Posted by Jklmiller    The Palace of Versailles was the principal residence of the French kings from the time of Louis XIV to Louis XVI. Embellished by several generations of architects, sculptors, decorators and landscape architects, it provided Europe with a model of the ideal royal residence for over a century.

properties.name: Panthéon, Paris
properties.description: Posted by Jklmillerjardin du luxembourgThe Panthéon is a building in the Latin Quarter in Paris, France. It was originally built as a church dedicated to St. Genevieve, but after many vicissitudes now combines liturgical functions with its role as a famous burial place. It is an early example of Neoclassicism, with a façade modelled on the Pantheon in Rome, surmounted by a small dome that owes some of its character to Bramante\'s "Tempietto". Located in the Ve arrondissement on the top of Montagne Sainte-Geneviève, the Panthéon looks out over all of Paris.

properties.name: Place du Palais Royal
properties.description: Posted by Jklmiller48.862557000 2.33674900The Palais-Royal is a palace and garden north of the Louvre in the Ier arrondissement of Paris. Opposite the north wing of the Louvre, its famous forecourt (cour d\'honneur) screened with columns (since 1986 containing Daniel Buren\'s site-specific artpiece) faces the Place du Palais-Royal, which was much enlarged by Baron Haussmann after the Rue de Rivoli was built for Napoleon.

properties.name: Roman and Romanesque Monuments of Arles
properties.description: Posted by Jklmiller    Arles is a good example of the adaptation of an ancient city to medieval European civilization. It has some impressive Roman monuments, of which the earliest

properties.name: Royal Saltworks of Arc-et-Senans
properties.description: Posted by Jklmiller    The Royal Saltworks of Arc-et-Senans, near Besançon, was built by Claude-Nicolas Ledoux. Its construction, begun in 1775 during the reign of Louis XVI, was the first major achievement of industrial architecture, reflecting the ideal of progress of the Enlightenment. This vast, semicircular complex was designed to permit a rational and hierarchical organization of work and was to have been followed by the building of an ideal city, a project that was never realized.

properties.name: Solesmes Abbey
properties.description: Posted by JklmillersolesmesThe abbey St-Pierre-de-Solesmes, founded in 1010, is a Benedictine abbey. It is best known for its cultivation of the Roman Catholic liturgy and in particular Gregorian chant. Dom Prosper Gueranger, the famous 19th century abbot of Solesmes, was largely responsible for the restoration of the Benedictine Order in France.

properties.name: Vézelay, Church and Hill
properties.description: Posted by Jklmiller    Shortly after its foundation in the 9th century, the Benedictine abbey of Vézelay acquired the relics of St Mary Magdalene and since then it has been an important place of pilgrimage. St Bernard preached the Second Crusade there in 1146 and Richard the Lion-Hearted and Philip II Augustus met there to leave for the Third Crusade in 1190. With its sculpted capitals and portal, the Madeleine of Vézelay
